questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of graph in computer science?

explanations.a: Incorrect. An undirected graph is a valid type of graph in computer science where edges have no direction, meaning connections between vertices are bidirectional.
explanations.b: Correct! A bar graph is a type of statistical chart used for data visualization, not a graph data structure in computer science.
explanations.c: Incorrect. A directed graph (digraph) is a fundamental graph type in computer science where edges have direction, indicating one-way relationships between vertices.
explanations.d: Incorrect. A weighted graph is a valid graph type in computer science where edges have numerical values (weights) representing costs, distances, or other metrics.

questions.question: What is vertex coloring of a graph?

answers.a: A condition where any two vertices having a common edge should not have same color
answers.b: A condition where any two vertices having a common edge should always have same color
answers.c: A condition where all vertices should have a different color
answers.d: A condition where all vertices should have same color

explanations.a: Correct! Vertex coloring requires that adjacent vertices (those connected by an edge) must have different colors. This ensures no two connected vertices share the same color.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This is the opposite of vertex coloring rules. Connected vertices must have different colors, not the same color.
explanations.c: Incorrect. While vertices connected by edges must have different colors, vertices that aren't connected can share the same color. Not all vertices need different colors.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Having all vertices the same color would violate the basic rule of vertex coloring, as adjacent vertices would have the same color.

questions.question: In a properly vertex-coloured graph, what can you say about the colours of connected vertices (vertices with an edge between them)?

answers.a: They must all have the same colour
answers.b: They must all have different colours

explanations.a: Incorrect. Connected vertices cannot have the same color in a proper vertex coloring - this would violate the basic rule of graph coloring.
explanations.b: Correct! In a properly vertex-colored graph, any two vertices that share an edge (connected vertices) must have different colors to maintain a valid coloring.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Connected vertices cannot have any arbitrary color - they must have different colors to maintain a proper vertex coloring.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The statement that connected vertices must have different colors is true, making option b the correct answer.

questions.question: A graph G has a chromatic number of 2. What can you conclude about G?

answers.c: G can only be coloured with exactly 2 colours.
answers.d: G must have an even number of vertices.

explanations.a: Incorrect. A complete graph with n vertices requires n colors, so it cannot have a chromatic number of 2 unless it has only 2 vertices.
explanations.b: Correct! A graph with chromatic number 2 is bipartite, meaning its vertices can be divided into two independent sets where no vertices within the same set are connected.
explanations.c: Incorrect. While the graph can be colored with 2 colors, it can also be colored with more colors. The chromatic number represents the minimum number of colors needed.
explanations.d: Incorrect. A bipartite graph (chromatic number 2) can have either an even or odd number of vertices.

questions.question: A friend claims they coloured a graph with 10 vertices and only needed 1 colour.  Is this possible?

answers.a: No, this is not possible for any graph with more than 1 vertex
answers.b: Yes, it's always possible to colour any graph with just 1 colour
answers.c: It depends on the specific connections in the graph

explanations.a: Incorrect. A graph with no edges (null graph) can be colored with just one color, regardless of the number of vertices.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Most graphs require multiple colors due to connections between vertices.
explanations.c: Correct! If the graph has no edges (null graph), it can be colored with one color. If it has any edges, it needs at least two colors.
explanations.d: Incorrect. It's not about probability - it depends entirely on whether the graph has any edges.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of colors needed to properly color a cycle graph with 5 vertices (C5)?

explanations.a: Incorrect. A cycle graph with 5 vertices cannot be colored with just 2 colors as it's not bipartite.
explanations.b: Correct! A cycle graph with 5 vertices (C5) requires exactly 3 colors for proper vertex coloring. This is because it forms an odd cycle.
explanations.c: Incorrect. While 4 colors would work, it's not the minimum number needed. C5 can be properly colored with just 3 colors.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Using 5 colors would work but is excessive. The minimum number needed is 3 colors.

questions.question: What is the chromatic number of a complete graph with n vertices (Kn)?

explanations.a: Incorrect. A complete graph needs different colors for each vertex as every vertex is connected to every other vertex.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Two colors are only sufficient for a complete graph with 2 vertices (K2).
explanations.c: Incorrect. Half the number of vertices is not sufficient as every vertex in a complete graph is connected to every other vertex.
explanations.d: Correct! In a complete graph, every vertex is connected to every other vertex, so each vertex must have a different color, requiring n colors.

questions.question: In graph coloring, what is Brooks' theorem?

answers.a: Every graph can be colored with maximum degree + 1 colors
answers.b: For any connected graph G that is not complete or an odd cycle, χ(G) ≤ Δ(G)
answers.c: All planar graphs can be colored with 4 colors
answers.d: The chromatic number is always equal to the maximum degree

explanations.a: Incorrect. While this is often true, Brooks' theorem is more specific about when exactly this bound can be improved.
explanations.b: Correct! Brooks' theorem states that for any connected graph G that is neither a complete graph nor an odd cycle, the chromatic number χ(G) is at most equal to the maximum degree Δ(G) of the graph.
explanations.c: Incorrect. This is the Four Color Theorem, not Brooks' theorem.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The chromatic number can be less than the maximum degree in many cases.

questions.question: What is the Mycielski construction and what does it prove about graph coloring?

answers.a: It creates planar graphs with chromatic number 4
answers.b: It generates graphs with high chromatic number and low clique number
answers.c: It proves that all graphs are 3-colorable
answers.d: It shows that all graphs need at least n colors

explanations.a: Incorrect. The Mycielski construction is not specifically related to planar graphs or 4-coloring.
explanations.b: Correct! The Mycielski construction is a method for creating graphs with arbitrarily high chromatic numbers while keeping the clique number low, disproving the conjecture that graphs with high chromatic numbers must contain large complete subgraphs.
explanations.c: Incorrect. In fact, it proves the opposite by constructing graphs that need more than 3 colors.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The construction shows that graphs can need many colors even without containing large complete subgraphs.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of word analysis in natural language processing?

answers.b: To understand the grammatical and morphological features of words
answers.c: To count the number of words in a text

explanations.a: Incorrect. While translation is a use case, word analysis focuses on understanding word structure and features.
explanations.b: Correct! Word analysis helps identify grammatical categories, morphological features, and word relationships.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Word counting is a simple task that doesn't require detailed word analysis.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Alphabetical arrangement is a basic sorting task, not the purpose of word analysis.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a common feature analyzed in word analysis?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Gender is an important grammatical feature analyzed in many languages.
explanations.b: Correct! Font size is a visual presentation feature, not a linguistic feature of words.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Number (singular/plural) is a fundamental grammatical feature.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Case is a crucial grammatical feature in many languages.

questions.question: What is the difference between 'root' and 'stem' in word analysis?

answers.a: They are exactly the same thing
answers.b: Root is the basic form, while stem includes additional affixes
answers.c: Root is always longer than stem
answers.d: Stem is always in present tense

explanations.a: Incorrect. While related, root and stem have distinct linguistic definitions.
explanations.b: Correct! The root is the basic form of a word, while the stem is the root plus any derivational affixes.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Length is not a defining characteristic of either root or stem.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Tense is not a defining feature of stems.

questions.question: In the context of word analysis, what is the significance of the 'script' feature?

answers.a: It determines the font style of the word
answers.b: It indicates the writing system used (e.g., roman, devanagari)

explanations.a: Incorrect. Script is not about font styling but about the writing system.
explanations.b: Correct! Script indicates the writing system used, such as roman for English or devanagari for Hindi.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Pronunciation is handled by phonetics, not script.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Word origin is studied in etymology, not script analysis.

questions.question: How does gender affect word analysis in languages like Hindi?

answers.b: It influences agreement patterns with verbs and adjectives
answers.c: It only matters in formal writing
answers.d: It's only relevant for plural forms

explanations.a: Incorrect. Gender affects many parts of speech, not just pronouns.
explanations.b: Correct! Gender influences how words agree with other elements in the sentence, affecting verbs, adjectives, and other modifiers.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Gender is a fundamental grammatical feature that applies in all contexts.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Gender affects both singular and plural forms.

questions.question: What is the relationship between tense and aspect in word analysis?

answers.b: Tense indicates when an action occurs, while aspect shows how it unfolds over time
answers.c: Tense is only for verbs, aspect is for nouns
answers.d: Aspect is more important than tense

explanations.a: Incorrect. Tense and aspect are distinct grammatical categories.
explanations.b: Correct! Tense locates an action in time, while aspect describes its temporal structure or flow.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Both tense and aspect primarily apply to verbs.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Both are equally important in different contexts.

questions.question: In word analysis, what is the significance of case marking in languages like Hindi?

answers.b: It indicates the grammatical function of words in a sentence
answers.c: It's only used in formal writing
answers.d: It's the same as gender marking

explanations.a: Incorrect. Case marking affects more than just word order.
explanations.b: Correct! Case marking shows the grammatical role of words (subject, object, etc.) in the sentence.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Case marking is a fundamental grammatical feature used in all contexts.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Case and gender are distinct grammatical categories.

questions.question: How does the concept of 'person' in word analysis differ between English and Hindi?

answers.a: It's exactly the same in both languages
answers.b: Hindi has more complex person marking that interacts with gender and number
answers.d: Person marking is only for pronouns

explanations.a: Incorrect. The two languages handle person marking differently.
explanations.b: Correct! Hindi's person marking is more complex, interacting with gender and number in verb agreement.
explanations.c: Incorrect. English does use person marking, particularly in verbs.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Person marking affects verbs and other parts of speech.

questions.question: What is the role of 'number' in word analysis across different languages?

answers.b: It influences agreement patterns across multiple word classes
answers.d: It's the same in all languages

explanations.a: Incorrect. Number affects verbs, adjectives, and other parts of speech.
explanations.b: Correct! Number influences agreement patterns across nouns, verbs, adjectives, and other word classes.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Number is a grammatical feature, not just about counting.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Different languages handle number marking differently.
